author: COLLEEN HAWKES
title: Cool kindergarten in Japan takes 'playing house' to a whole new level
text:
Cool kindergarten in Japan takes 'playing house' to a whole new level COLLEEN HAWKES Last updated 10:35, February 24 2017 HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
Dinner's ready - the children are free to role play without interference by adults. 
Young children love to "play house", but seldom do they get to do it in a Wendy house as cool as this one. 
The Ouchi – the Japanese word for house – is a new building within a building. It's an architect-designed playhouse for the lucky pre-schoolers at a kindergarten in Saga, Japan. 
The architects at Hibinosekkei , who worked on the project with Youji no Shiro and Kids Design Labo, say they were asked to build an area in the school where children can develop their creativity through role playing. HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
This new playhouse is a small-scale replica of a house that sits within a kindergarten building in Saga, Japan. 
"We wanted to break away from the existing toys and playground kindergarten typology, and design the space in sync with our belief that when children role play, they try imitating adults. With this in mind, we decided to design one mini house within the existing building, where children can imitate their parents and their real world activities." 
READ MORE: HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
The architects say the Ouchi, as it is called, is designed to let children play creatively. 
Ouchi somes equipped with a kitchen, dining table, sink, cupboards, laundry and wood stove. Tucked away in the doors and drawers in the kitchen are frying pans, forks, knives, spoons, cups, a toaster, rice cooker, chopping board and pots. There's even a refrigerator. 
"Children may enact their mothers, by making a meal from various ingredients, decorating the table with flowers, and also arranging dishes while dining," the architects say. 
"After the meal, children may also clean and wash dishes in the sink. They may turn on the heater during cold, and eat at the terrace when sunny. They can put clothes into the washing machine and then dry them." HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
Plywood walls and timber furniture feature throughout the interior. 
The team says the children were brought to the site during construction to give them a first-thand touch-and-feel experience of a carpenter's job. 
"By this, we are challenging the conventional methods and creating opportunities to increase the possibility of exploration and curiosity amongst children, by keeping them in close contact with the adult jobs." 
The architects also have a few words to say about conventional toys and playground equipment. HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
At one end, stairs lead up to a small mezzanine sitting area. 
"These are produced to cope with the law of Product Liability, and hence fashioned cautiously towards customer security and spoon-fed guidance. This inhibits the creativity and curiosity amongst children, by making things straight and clear and hence eradicating the possibility of exploration. 
"To handle the situation well, our design is based on this essential concept, where children could continuously create challenge and grow. 
"To complete this concept, it's essential to allow children to explore in here with full freedom and less direct interference from the teachers. The owner understands this well and hence keeps an eye on children from a distance. HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
Children can pretend to make meals and clean up afterwards. 
"As a result, we have the scenes where children continuously create and challenge with wonderful smiles on their face. We are looking forward to the future they will make for themselves." HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
Utensils include pots and frying pans, as well as crockery and cutlery. HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
Children hang clothes out to dry on racks within the laundry. HIBINOSEKKEI/YOUJI NO SHIRO 
The interior includes a table and chairs, wood stove, fully equipped kitchen and laundry. - Stuff
